The Marine Environment","description":"

This course covers aspects of both the physical and biological environments of the sea and their inter-relationships. It depicts marine science as a body of knowledge and a process of continual enquiry and testing of ideas. It considers human impacts on the marine environments and how the principles and methods of science in general are used to predict and to solve the problems created by human activities.



The course includes discussion of: i) the marine environment, its physical, geological, chemical and biological characteristics and their interactions; ii) beach safety and marine biodiversity and iii) the effects of development and climate change on the marine environment and how science can contribute to providing solutions to these problems.

Throughout the course, emphasis is placed on case studies. Two to three field excursions (generally held on a weekend) take the place of weekly practicals to supplement the lectures.

Introductory Marine Science","description":"

This course introduces students to a cross-section of the theory and application of marine science and includes an opportunity to experience field research. Spanning the disciplines of geology, chemistry, physics, and biology, it provides a fundamental understanding of how oceans work. Topics covered are: the chemistry of seawater; air-sea interactions; ocean circulation; waves, tides, and coastlines; biological productivity and biological diversity. Note/s: This course might include compulsory field work, and if so personal costs will be incurred.

The final exam will take place during the scheduled exam period.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c7de2dd11bb56010d5fb0fabdc4bcbb4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c7de2dd11bb56010d5fb0fabdc4bcbb5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"cfde2dd11bb56010d5fb0fabdc4bcbb4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"0bde2dd11bb56010d5fb0fabdc4bcbb8","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Field trip report","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"35","description":"

Students work in groups for field trip project conducted at Smiths Lake in week 5. Students prepare individual reference lists and a 2 page literature review (not marked but must be completed end of week 4, and feedback will be provided). Students complete a field project in groups but write an individual report (2hrs under exam conditions) in the format of a scientific paper on the group collected data at the end of the field trip (end week 5). Feedback in the form of written reports and in class discussion (end week 6). 

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"c7de2dd11bb56010d5fb0fabdc4bcbb4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"c7de2dd11bb56010d5fb0fabdc4bcbb5","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"cfde2dd11bb56010d5fb0fabdc4bcbb4","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"9bde2dd11bb56010d5fb0fabdc4bcbc1","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar Presentation","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"20","description":"

Overall this assessment task is worth 20% and has two steps.

  1. Students submit a three minute seminar via powerpoint (4-5 slides max.) on a Research paper selected for a list of papers provide (10%). These are posted to moodle. Due week 6.
  2. Students provide brief critical review of other students seminars after viewing them on Moodle using a marking rubric provided (10%). Due week 7. Feedback for both components week 8 via moodle and in class.

Availability of general education courses outside of the owning Faculty may be restricted by the Program Authority, usually because they are closely related to the study area of the student’s program."}],"credit_points_header":"6 Units of Credit","eqivalents":[],"exclusion":[],"search_title":"MSCI2060 - Coral Reefs in a Changing Climate","description":"

Tropical coral reefs are one of the world’s most diverse and important ecosystems. However coral reefs are also very sensitive ecosystems. Over the last few years we have seen mass bleaching events and unprecedented levels of coral mortality around the world. Like many other ecosystems, coral reefs are under threat from a warming and acidifying ocean. To mitigate against future damage, we need to understand these threatened ecosystems, how they are affected by the physical and chemical environment, and how threats can be reduced to converse the coral reef systems.


This course aims to provide you with that broad understanding of the systems, threats and conversation efforts. You will learn about  the components that make up a coral reef system: the coral animal/plant symbiosis, fish, algae, invertebrates and larger mammals, and the interactions between them. You will also learn about the physical environment: temperature, ocean currents, ocean chemistry that strongly affect the coral system, the climate change and how all these systems are being affected by climate change. Finally, you will investigate major threats faced by coral reefs and explore how we can manage and conserve these ecosystems.


The course will be delivered in a combination of online and on-field modes. You will be able to access online modules to gain an understanding of the coral ecosystems and prepare for the  field trip at Lady Elliot Island Reef Resort. On the island you will be introduced to the incredible flora and fauna and conduct a field experiment on the reef.


The course will include a compulsory field trip to Lady Elliot Island that will incur personal costs to students.

","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"af13ccfddb825490eb6b147a3a96198a","name":"Blended in-person / online - Intensive"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Reef walk report (on island)","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"10","description":"

Students undertake reef walk (in the coral lagoon) and are exposed to the flora and fauna of the reef by members of staff. After the walk, they are required to write a 700 word individual report identifying and describing a subset of 5-10 species, explaining their ecosystem function, and reviewing strategies for species success

Report written, marked and returned on-island

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"7313ccfddb825490eb6b147a3a96198f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7b13ccfddb825490eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7b13ccfddb825490eb6b147a3a96198e","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3313ccfddb825490eb6b147a3a9619b0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Field Experiment","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"25","description":"

Students will work within a group of 7 under supervision and support of 1 staff member. They will develop a hypothesis about the coral reef and select a suitable experiment to test the hypothesis from a given list of accessible experiments. With guidance from their supervisor, they will conduct the experiment, collect data, analyse them and draw conclusion on the hypothesis.

For assessment, students will present on the field experiment to their peers (12 minute per group plus 5 minute Q&A). As individuals, they will be asked to prepare a written scientific report. 

Oral Presentation accounts for 8% and individual written report accounts for 17%.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"7313ccfddb825490eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"7313ccfddb825490eb6b147a3a96198e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"7313ccfddb825490eb6b147a3a96198f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3f13ccfddb825490eb6b147a3a961990","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Media article","assessment_type":{"label":"Assignment","value":"assignment"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

Prior to the field trip to the island, students will choose a topic of interest from a given list. Student will research the topic using a variety of sources including scientific reports. Students will put together a short ABC news-style report on the topic in media of their choice (short print article, web article, video, podcast etc)

On the first day on the island, students will be asked to present their media article (3 minute presentation) to their peers. Their peers will be asked to review the presentation and provide feedback for improvement and further studies.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"7313ccfddb825490eb6b147a3a96198f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7b13ccfddb825490eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7b13ccfddb825490eb6b147a3a96198f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"6423ccfddb825490eb6b147a3a9619d5","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"On line quizzes/tests","assessment_type":{"label":"Test","value":"test"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"50","description":"

Foundational concepts will be taught pre-island via online modules, linked material, required reading and facilitated tutorials. These basic concepts will be assessed using online quizzes with immediate feedback so that students can revisit topics where necessary to reinforce their understanding of the topics. A summative post-island online test will be designed to assess students learning of the whole course including their learning on the island.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO6","cl_id":"7313ccfddb825490eb6b147a3a96198e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO7","cl_id":"7313ccfddb825490eb6b147a3a96198f","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"7713ccfddb825490eb6b147a3a96198c","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"7b13ccfddb825490eb6b147a3a96198d","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"7b13ccfddb825490eb6b147a3a96198e","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"7b13ccfddb825490eb6b147a3a96198f","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"8823ccfddb825490eb6b147a3a9619b4","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/MSCI2060.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

contentlets.description:
Tropical coral reefs are one of the world’s most diverse and important ecosystems. However coral reefs are also very sensitive ecosystems. Over the last few years we have seen mass bleaching events and unprecedented levels of coral mortality around the world. Like many other ecosystems, coral reefs are under threat from a warming and acidifying ocean. To mitigate against future damage, we need to understand these threatened ecosystems, how they are affected by the physical and chemical environment, and how threats can be reduced to converse the coral reef systems.

This course aims to provide you with that broad understanding of the systems, threats and conversation efforts. You will learn about  the components that make up a coral reef system: the coral animal/plant symbiosis, fish, algae, invertebrates and larger mammals, and the interactions between them. You will also learn about the physical environment: temperature, ocean currents, ocean chemistry that strongly affect the coral system, the climate change and how all these systems are being affected by climate change. Finally, you will investigate major threats faced by coral reefs and explore how we can manage and conserve these ecosystems.

The course will be delivered in a combination of online and on-field modes. You will be able to access online modules to gain an understanding of the coral ecosystems and prepare for the  field trip at Lady Elliot Island Reef Resort. The course will include a compulsory field trip to Lady Elliot Island that will incur personal costs to students.

The way water circulates around the oceans has direct impacts on climate as well as marine ecology. In this course, we will dive into the way the ocean works. From the East Australian Current to the global conveyor belt, and from eddies to beach waves. We will cover the dynamics and properties of ocean water and the way those are measured, and apply it to problems like El Nino, the great garbage patches and Global Warming. Assumed knowledge: Any 6 Units of Credit of Level I Mathematics.

The way water circulates around the oceans has direct impacts on climate as well as marine ecology. In this course, we will dive into the way the ocean works. From the East Australian Current to the global conveyor belt, and from eddies to beach waves. We will cover the dynamics and properties of ocean water and the way those are measured, and apply it to problems like El Nino, the great garbage patches and Global Warming. Assumed knowledge: sufficient undergraduate level of mathematics.

Examines marine pelagic and estuarine habitats and the practical application of theory to the ocean environment and its effect on the life of marine organisms. Emphasis is placed on the biology of phytoplankton, zooplankton and fish, together with the study of fisheries. Also looks at management, marine technology, computer simulations, conservation, other marine vertebrates, aquaculture and environmental concerns, and technical skills, taxonomy and sampling design. Note: A field trip may be held during the mid-session break and personal costs may be incurred. Session 2Studies the ecology of marine and freshwater systems, emphasising benthic communities; population and community dynamics of these systems; evolution of life histories in the light of the constraints of aquatic systems. Emphasis is on experimental approaches to aquatic ecology. Special topics considered include chemical ecology, plant/herbivore ecology, and applied aspects of the topic such as mariculture, and there is a section on the biology and taxonomy of marine algae (seaweeds).


Note: Fieldwork is an important component of the course and personal costs may be incurred.


Assumed knowledge:


  • BIOS2031 Biology of Invertebrate or equivalent subject taken at undergraduate level, and
  • BEES2041 Data analysis: Life and earth science or equivalent statistical analysis taken at undergraduate level
","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"0581b4bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a96196d","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Project","assessment_type":{"label":"Project","value":"project"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"30","description":"

Students write up the findings of the field trip projects. Alternatively, students can source their own life table data. They are required to analyse and interpret their data, and present their findings in the form of a scientific paper. Feedback and marks from academic staff will be provided via Moodle within two weeks of submission

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"0981b4bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961969","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4181b4bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961920","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4181b4bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961961","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8d81b4bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961963","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c981b4bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961966","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"3c8174bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619db","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Essay","assessment_type":{"label":"Essay","value":"essay"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

The essay is a review on age and growth in fishes or marine invertebrates. 

The review should be started early in session, to assist with the project commencement. Topics should include the nature and function of scales, otoliths and other bones in fish or hard parts in marine invertebrates, the importance and application of age and growth determination in fisheries, mathematical growth models, larval ages and fisheries oceanography, examples of year class strength variation and recruitment, the effect of temperature and food abundance, and microchemistry. The review should emphasise your background and future interests (e.g. tropical, temperate, polar, aquaculture, freshwater, larval, adult, fish, squid, gastropod, bivalve, sea urchin etc.).  You should seek out your own references - first examining texts, and then some primary literature. Where appropriate, be critical of the studies.

Marks and comments will be returned within two weeks of submission

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"0981b4bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961969","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4181b4bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961920","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4181b4bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961961","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"c981b4bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961966","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"748174bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a9619e0","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Seminar or Debate","assessment_type":{"label":"Presentation","value":"presentation"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"10","description":"

Students can either present an individual seminar based on thier essay, or participate in the debates held with BIOS3681 students. Feedback and marks from academic staff are provided on Moodle one week after the presentations.

Seminar:

Students present a 10-minute seminar based on thier essay. The presentation should include a powerpoint presentation. Students will also prepare and distribute for other students a 400 word abstract 7 days before, which will be part of the assessment

Debates:

In teams, students perform a debate in class on a given topic relating to a contemporary marine issue. Each group is assigned either “for” or “against”, and are required to argue that side of the argument. Each team then researches the topic, and prepares a case for their argument, which they present to the class with team member of the team presenting. After they present their case, there is question time from the opposing team, and the students need to rebut any arguments raised. Students are assessed on their knowledge of the topic and the quality of their arguments.

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"0981b4bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961969","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"4181b4bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961920","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"4181b4bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961961","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"8d81b4bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961963","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b881b4bbdb751c50eb6b147a3a961916","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Exam","assessment_type":{"label":"Examination","value":"examination"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"40","description":"

The final exam assesses student comprehension of all material covered in course

This Unit of Study will introduce students to current research undertaken in various disciplines of marine science in Australia. It will be a multi-institutional unit taught at the Sydney Institute of Marine Science (SIMS) with contributions from the four University partners of SIMS. Lectures and tutorials will be taught by leading marine science researchers. Topics will cover physical and biological oceanography, climate change, molecular ecology, aquaculture, marine biology and marine geosciences. In practical classes, students will analyse and interpret remote-sensing data from the Integrated Marine Observing System (IMOS), which provides comprehensive information on the biological and physical processes of Australia's coastal and oceanic waters.


Notes:


  • Students are required to attend the course at the Sydney Institute of Marine Science throughout semester.
  • Assumed knowledge for this course is sufficient knowledge of statistical analysis at undergraduate level: sampling strategies, t-test and ANOVA, regression, residuals analysis, other general data analysis and manipulation using spreadsheets.

40% is for the final exam taken at SIMS, Mosman which is based on the content taught in the practicals and lectures.

\n","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"34493ae5db3b1850eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"34493ae5db3b1850eb6b147a3a9619c9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3c493ae5db3b1850eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3c493ae5db3b1850eb6b147a3a9619c9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b4493ae5db3b1850eb6b147a3a9619c7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"b0493ae5db3b1850eb6b147a3a9619cb","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Practical participation & reports","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"1","weighting":"60","description":"

Practical participation and reports contains six modules, each module is worth 10%. Assessment mark is based on homework from the practicals that students undertake at SIMS, Mosman. The practicals are run as a series of modules on different topics in marine science, but based around the Integrated Marine Observing System (IMOS). Each module is taught over 2-3 weeks. The homework consists of a series of short answer questions based on the work done in the module and is due 1 week after the module finishes. We aim to provide students with feedback 1 week after they have handed in. Feedback includes the correct answers to the questions as well as comments on their work if necessary. Each module is taught and marked by a different expert in that area of Marine Science. If students require any additional feedback they are able to contact the appropriate academic. Last year we ran five modules. Homework for four of the modules was each worth 10% and these modules were each run over 2 practical sessions, the physical oceanography module was run over 3 practical sessions and was worth 20% (60% for all the homework).

\n","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"34493ae5db3b1850eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"34493ae5db3b1850eb6b147a3a9619c9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"3c493ae5db3b1850eb6b147a3a9619c8","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"3c493ae5db3b1850eb6b147a3a9619c9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"b4493ae5db3b1850eb6b147a3a9619c7","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"c5493ae5db3b1850eb6b147a3a9619d4","links":[]}]}],"inactive_course_alert":null,"timetableURL":"http://timetable.unsw.edu.au/2021/MSCI6681.html","subject_sample_text_staticcontent":"To access course outline, please visit:","links":[]}

This Unit of Study will introduce students to current research undertaken in various disciplines of marine science in Australia. It will be a multi-institutional unit taught at the Sydney Institute of Marine Science (SIMS) with contributions from the four University partners of SIMS. Lectures and tutorials will be taught by leading marine science researchers. Topics will cover physical and biological oceanography, climate change, molecular ecology, aquaculture, marine biology and marine geosciences. In practical classes, students will analyse and interpret remote-sensing data from the Integrated Marine Observing System (IMOS), which provides comprehensive information on the biological and physical processes of Australia's coastal and oceanic waters.


Notes:


  • Students are required to attend the course at the Sydney Institute of Marine Science throughout semester.
  • Assumed knowledge for this course is sufficient knowledge of statistical analysis at undergraduate level: sampling strategies, t-test and ANOVA, regression, residuals analysis, other general data analysis and manipulation using spreadsheets.

Practical participation and reports contains six modules, each module is worth 10%. Assessment mark is based on homework from the practicals that students undertake at SIMS, Mosman. The practicals are run as a series of modules on different topics in marine science, but based around the Integrated Marine Observing System (IMOS). Each module is taught over 2-3 weeks. The homework consists of a series of short answer questions based on the work done in the module and is due 1 week after the module finishes. We aim to provide students with feedback 1 week after they have handed in. Feedback includes the correct answers to the questions as well as comments on their work if necessary. Each module is taught and marked by a different expert in that area of Marine Science. If students require any additional feedback they are able to contact the appropriate academic. Last year we ran five modules. Homework for four of the modules was each worth 10% and these modules were each run over 2 practical sessions, the physical oceanography module was run over 3 practical sessions and was worth 20% (60% for all the homework).

Topics will cover physical and biological oceanography, climate change, molecular ecology, aquaculture, marine biology and marine geosciences. In practical classes, students will analyse and interpret remote-sensing data from the Integrated Marine Observing System (IMOS), which provides comprehensive information on the biological and physical processes of Australia's coastal and oceanic waters.

Notes:

This course introduces the varied life histories of marine organisms, and focuses on aspects of an organisms life history that may make it vulnerable to anthropogenic activities. The course then draws on this background to demonstrate how to best target conservation measures both to conserve individual species and maintain diverse marine communities. Special topics considered include chemical ecology and ecotoxicology, fish ecology, plant/herbivore ecology, and marine protected areas.Notes:1) Field excursions are compulsory and will involve additional expense to the individual student; 2) Students will be required to attend Sydney Institute of Marine Science for field training during the mid-semester break;3) This course is restricted to students undertaking the Master of Conservation Biology program. Enrolment of students studying other programs is subject to availability and approval by the Course Authority.","hb_assessments":[{"delivery_variation":{"cl_id":"c6f3ea27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619bd","name":"Blended in-person / online - Standard (usually weekly or fortnightly)"},"assessments":[{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Plant-herbivore interactions","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"3","weighting":"20","description":"

Students are required to report the results of an experiment carried out during one of the practicals. The purpose of the practical is to teach some techniques of experimental design and execution in field experiments, and data analysis. The aim of this field experiment is to determine whether local herbivores affect the distribution and/or abundance of algae on our local shores. Students summarise the experiment and the findings in the form of a scientific report submitted to Marine Ecology Progress Series.

Marks and written comments from academic staff and demonstrators will be provided within one week of assignment submission

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO2","cl_id":"35f3ea27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619b1","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"71f3ea27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8ef3ea27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619b6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO5","cl_id":"caf3ea27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619b9","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f5f3ea27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"21f3ea27dbf99850eb6b147a3a961994","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Independent field project report","assessment_type":{"label":"Report","value":"report"},"assessment_id":"4","weighting":"25","description":"

Groups of students will sign up for research topics that can be addressed through field work in local marine and freshwater habitats. A list of topics will be made available through Moodle and will be discussed in the practicals. In this exercise, students will gain experience in carrying out independent research, including the formulation of their own hypotheses and sampling designs, and data collection, analysis, and interpretation, and communication of results. Students are required to summarise their findings in a report in the form of a scientific journal article.

Each group is also required to present a short talk on their field project. The aim is to educate the rest of the class on what was done and what was found. The presentation should include background information on your project, the specific hypotheses you aimed to test, the methods used to test the hypotheses, plus results and their interpretation.

Marks and written comments from academic staff and demonstrators will be provided within two weeks of assignment submission

","learning_outcomes":[{"value":"CLO3","cl_id":"71f3ea27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619b4","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO4","cl_id":"8ef3ea27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619b6","key":"code"},{"value":"CLO1","cl_id":"f5f3ea27dbf99850eb6b147a3a9619ae","key":"code"}],"delivery_variations":[],"applies_to_all_delivery_variations":"true","cl_id":"adf3ea27dbf99850eb6b147a3a96198a","links":[]},{"individual":{"label":null,"value":null},"assessment_name":"Opinions in Ecology","assessment_type":{"label":"Other","value":"other"},"assessment_id":"2","weighting":"15","description":"

In this exercise, students will select a topic that has been contentious and write an article that argues for one side of the debate (rather than reviews both sides of the debate). In doing so, you will need to acknowledge the criticisms of the concept you are supporting, and then argue against those criticisms. To do this successfully, you will need to read the literature critically, and select arguments and examples that support your side of the debate. The article should be written in the style of a popular science article, and may be illustrated with figures and tables. The topics will emphasise those issues that link marine and aquatic ecology to practical problems in conservation and management of coastal environments. It is in these areas that scientists need to be able to clearly argue their point of view.

Marks and written comments from academic staff and demonstrators will be provided within two weeks of assignment submission

contentlets.description: Ecology of marine, estuarine and freshwater systems, and population /community dynamics of these systems. This course introduces the varied life histories of marine organisms, and focuses on aspects of an organisms life history that may make it vulnerable to anthropogenic activities. The course then draws on this background to demonstrate how to best target conservation measures both to conserve individual species and maintain diverse marine communities. Special topics considered include chemical ecology and ecotoxicology, fish ecology, plant/herbivore ecology, and marine protected areas.Notes:1) Field excursions are compulsory and will involve additional expense to the individual student; 2) Students will be required to attend Sydney Institute of Marine Science for field training during the mid-semester break;3) This course is restricted to students undertaking the Master of Conservation Biology program. Enrolment of students studying other programs is subject to availability and approval by the Course Authority.
contentlets.title: Conservation in Aquatic Ecosystems
